required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of the Improvement of Independence by the Resumption of a Significant Activity Such as a Cooking Workshop in Adult Patients With Stroke Benefiting From Traditional Rehabilitation
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Improvement of Independence by the Resumption of a Significant Activity Such as a Cooking Workshop in Adult Patients With Stroke Benefiting From Traditional Rehabilitation

brief_summary.textblock: A non-randomized, monocentric, pilot study comparing the level of independence for each individual with significant resumption of activity in adult patients with stroke

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline level of independence in a population of adult patients with stroke having participated in cooking workshop at week 3
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of independence by Functional Independence Measure score

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the patient's quality of life
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of the patient's quality of life by the Medical Outcome Study (MOS)Short Form (SF-36 ) questionnaire
Evaluation of the patient's self-esteem by Rosenberg Self Estimate Scale

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient older than 18 years old
- Primary stroke or recurrence on stroke having no previous sequelae
- Stroke older than 3 weeks
- Ability to understand treatment and sufficient motivation
- Problem Activity Indicated in CMOP (Canadian Measure of Occupational Performance)
- Barthel Index > 60
- Patient who received oral and written information about the protocol and who did not show opposition to participate in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Dermatological pathology with wounds on the unhealed upper limbs
- Patient in contact and droplet isolation
- A psychiatric history requiring hospitalization in specialized settings for more than 2 months
- Any condition that may limit participation or interfere with analysis of results
